If a function is continuous at every point of a compact set `k`, then it is bounded on
some open neighborhood of `k`.

type:

  IsCompact k ‚Üí (‚àÄ x ‚àà k, ContinuousAt f x) ‚Üí ‚àÉ t, k ‚äÜ t ‚àß IsOpen t ‚àß Bornology.IsBounded (f '' t)
name: Metric.exists_isOpen_isBounded_image_of_isCompact_of_forall_continuousAt
docString:
If a function is continuous at every point of a compact set `k`, then it is bounded on
some open neighborhood of `k`.

Given a locally integrable function `f` from a measurable and topological space `(X, Œ£, Œº)` to a normed add commutative group `E` and a compact set `k ‚àà X`, there exists an open set `u ‚àà X` containing `k` such that `f` is integrable on `u`.

type:
‚àÄ {X : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  {f : X ‚Üí E} {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure X},
  MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable f Œº ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ {k : Set X}, IsCompact k ‚Üí ‚àÉ u, IsOpen u ‚àß k ‚äÜ u ‚àß MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn f u Œº
name: MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable.integrableOn_nhds_isCompact
docString: Given a locally integrable function `f` from a measurable and topological space `(X, Œ£, Œº)` to a normed add commutative group `E` and a compact set `k ‚àà X`, there exists an open set `u ‚àà X` containing `k` such that `f` is integrable on `u`.

This theorem states that for a parameterized integral of the form `x ‚Ü¶ ‚à´ y, f x y`, where `f` is a function that is continuous and uniformly vanishes outside a compact set `k`, the integral function depends continuously on `x`. This is under the conditions that `f` is continuous on the product of the set `s` and the universal set, and for any `p` in `s` and any `y` not in `k`, `f p y` is equal to zero. The spaces `X` and `Y` are topological, `Y` is measurable, `Œº` is a measure on `Y` finite on compact sets, and `E` is a normed additive commutative group which is also a real normed space.

type:
‚àÄ {X : Type u_1} {Y : Type u_2} {E : Type u_3} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Y]
  [inst_2 : MeasurableSpace Y] [inst_3 : OpensMeasurableSpace Y] {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Y}
  [inst_4 : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_5 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] {f : X ‚Üí Y ‚Üí E} {s : Set X} {k : Set Y}
  [inst_6 : MeasureTheory.IsFiniteMeasureOnCompacts Œº],
  IsCompact k ‚Üí
    ContinuousOn (Function.uncurry f) (s √óÀ¢ Set.univ) ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ (p : X) (x : Y), p ‚àà s ‚Üí x ‚àâ k ‚Üí f p x = 0) ‚Üí ContinuousOn (fun x => ‚à´ (y : Y), f x y ‚àÇŒº) s
name: continuousOn_integral_of_compact_support
docString: This theorem states that for a parameterized integral of the form `x ‚Ü¶ ‚à´ y, f x y`, where `f` is a function that is continuous and uniformly vanishes outside a compact set `k`, the integral function depends continuously on `x`. This is under the conditions that `f` is continuous on the product of the set `s` and the universal set, and for any `p` in `s` and any `y` not in `k`, `f p y` is equal to zero. The spaces `X` and `Y` are topological, `Y` is measurable, `Œº` is a measure on `Y` finite on compact sets, and `E` is a normed additive commutative group which is also a real normed space.

If a function is continuous on a neighborhood of a compact set `k`, then it is bounded on
some open neighborhood of `k`.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u} {Œ≤ : Type v} [inst : PseudoMetricSpace Œ±] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Œ≤] {k s : Set Œ≤} {f : Œ≤ ‚Üí Œ±},
  IsCompact k ‚Üí IsOpen s ‚Üí k ‚äÜ s ‚Üí ContinuousOn f s ‚Üí ‚àÉ t, k ‚äÜ t ‚àß IsOpen t ‚àß Bornology.IsBounded (f '' t)

docString:
If a function is continuous on a neighborhood of a compact set `k`, then it is bounded on

Given locally integrable function `f`, `C^n` smooth function `g` with compact support `k` independent of a parameter `s` from an open subset, if `g` is zero outside `k` for all points in `s`, then the convolution `(g x) * f` is `n` times continuously differentiable on `s`.

type:
‚àÄ {ùïú : Type uùïú} {G : Type uG} {E : Type uE} {E' : Type uE'} {F : Type uF} {P : Type uP} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E'] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_3 : RCLike ùïú] [inst_4 : NormedSpace ùïú E]
  [inst_5 : NormedSpace ùïú E'] [inst_6 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù F] [inst_7 : NormedSpace ùïú F] [inst_8 : CompleteSpace F]
  [inst_9 : MeasurableSpace G] [inst_10 : NormedAddCommGroup G] [inst_11 : BorelSpace G] [inst_12 : NormedSpace ùïú G]
  [inst_13 : NormedAddCommGroup P] [inst_14 : NormedSpace ùïú P] {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure G}
  [inst_15 : Œº.IsAddLeftInvariant] [inst_16 : Œº.IsNegInvariant] (L : E' ‚ÜíL[ùïú] E ‚ÜíL[ùïú] F) {s : Set P} {n : ‚Ñï‚àû}
  {v : P ‚Üí G},
  ContDiffOn ùïú n v s ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ {f : G ‚Üí E} {g : P ‚Üí G ‚Üí E'} {k : Set G},
      IsOpen s ‚Üí
        IsCompact k ‚Üí
          (‚àÄ (p : P) (x : G), p ‚àà s ‚Üí x ‚àâ k ‚Üí g p x = 0) ‚Üí
            MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable f Œº ‚Üí
              ContDiffOn ùïú n (‚Üøg) (s √óÀ¢ Set.univ) ‚Üí ContDiffOn ùïú n (fun x => convolution (g x) f L Œº (v x)) s
name: contDiffOn_convolution_left_with_param_comp
docString: Given locally integrable function `f`, `C^n` smooth function `g` with compact support `k` independent of a parameter `s` from an open subset, if `g` is zero outside `k` for all points in `s`, then the convolution `(g x) * f` is `n` times continuously differentiable on `s`.

This theorem is known as the Cauchy formula for the derivative of a holomorphic function. It states that for any normed additive commutative group `E`, any normed space over `‚ÑÇ` with `E` as base, and any complete space `E`, given an open set `U` in the complex plane, complex numbers `c` and `w‚ÇÄ`, a real number `R`, and a function `f` from complex numbers to `E`, if the closed ball centered at `c` with radius `R` is a subset of `U` and `f` is differentiable on `U` and `w‚ÇÄ` is in the open ball centered at `c` with radius `R`, then the integral of `f z` divided by `(z - w‚ÇÄ)¬≤` around the circle centered at `c` with radius `R`, scaled by the multiplicative inverse of `2œÄi`, equals the derivative of `f` at `w‚ÇÄ`. This is a crucial property of holomorphic functions and serves as the foundation for many results in complex analysis.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚ÑÇ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {U : Set ‚ÑÇ},
  IsOpen U ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ {c w‚ÇÄ : ‚ÑÇ} {R : ‚Ñù} {f : ‚ÑÇ ‚Üí E},
      Metric.closedBall c R ‚äÜ U ‚Üí
        DifferentiableOn ‚ÑÇ f U ‚Üí
          w‚ÇÄ ‚àà Metric.ball c R ‚Üí
            ((2 * ‚ÜëReal.pi * Complex.I)‚Åª¬π ‚Ä¢ ‚àÆ (z : ‚ÑÇ) in C(c, R), ((z - w‚ÇÄ) ^ 2)‚Åª¬π ‚Ä¢ f z) = deriv f w‚ÇÄ
name: Complex.two_pi_I_inv_smul_circleIntegral_sub_sq_inv_smul_of_differentiable
docString: This theorem is known as the Cauchy formula for the derivative of a holomorphic function. It states that for any normed additive commutative group `E`, any normed space over `‚ÑÇ` with `E` as base, and any complete space `E`, given an open set `U` in the complex plane, complex numbers `c` and `w‚ÇÄ`, a real number `R`, and a function `f` from complex numbers to `E`, if the closed ball centered at `c` with radius `R` is a subset of `U` and `f` is differentiable on `U` and `w‚ÇÄ` is in the open ball centered at `c` with radius `R`, then the integral of `f z` divided by `(z - w‚ÇÄ)¬≤` around the circle centered at `c` with radius `R`, scaled by the multiplicative inverse of `2œÄi`, equals the derivative of `f` at `w‚ÇÄ`. This is a crucial property of holomorphic functions and serves as the foundation for many results in complex analysis.

        ‚®Ö f,
          ‚®Ö (_ : Continuous f),
            ‚®Ö (_ : HasCompactSupport f), ‚®Ö (_ : Set.EqOn f 1 k), ‚®Ö (_ : 0 ‚â§ f), ENNReal.ofReal (‚à´ (x : X), f x ‚àÇŒº)
name: IsCompact.measure_eq_biInf_integral_hasCompactSupport
docString:
In a locally compact regular space with an inner regular measure, the measure of a compact
